headline.main: Five Dishes at La Promenade des Anglais

docs.snippet: The chef Alain Allegretti's menu is sometimes Nicois, sometimes Ligurian, sometimes neither, but it generally exhibits his command of modern French cuisine....
docs.abstract: The chef Alain Allegretti's menu is sometimes Nicois, sometimes Ligurian, sometimes neither, but it generally exhibits his command of modern French cuisine.

headline.main: Five Dishes at La Promenade des Anglais

docs.snippet: The chef Alain Allegretti's menu is sometimes Niçois, sometimes Ligurian, sometimes neither, but it generally exhibits his command of modern French cuisine....
docs.abstract: The chef Alain Allegretti's menu is sometimes Niçois, sometimes Ligurian, sometimes neither, but it generally exhibits his command of modern French cuisine.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Nice, France, La Promenade des Anglais is a walkway along the sea where you can stroll while checking out the array of bathing suits worn by the people lounging on blue chairs on the sand below.

headline.main: Lehman Still Doing Deals in a Second Life on Wall Street

docs.snippet: The Lehman Brothers estate is in its fourth year of administration in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, and like other Wall Street failures, it's not going away anytime soon....
docs.abstract: The Lehman Brothers estate is in its fourth year of administration in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, and like other Wall Street failures, it's not going away anytime soon.
docs.lead_paragraph: Things that refuse to die include Dracula, fungus, Jason from the "Friday the 13th" movies, zombies - and Lehman Brothers.

headline.main: Hedge Funds Will Be Winners If Greek Bailout Arrives

docs.snippet: A growing number of investors are loading up on Greek government securities that mature in March - just when Athens is hoping to receive a lifeline of as much as E30 billion, or $38 billion, from the European Union and the International Monetary F...
docs.abstract: A growing number of investors are loading up on Greek government securities that mature in March - just when Athens is hoping to receive a lifeline of as much as E30 billion, or $38 billion, from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, reports Landon Thomas Jr. for The New York Times.
